tn.ref: As dead flies ... so a little folly
tn.text: Just as flies can ruin perfume, so folly can ruin a person's reputation for wisdom and honor. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: The heart of a wise person ... the heart of a fool
tn.text: Here the word "heart" refers to the mind or will. AT: "The way a wise person thinks ... the way a fool thinks" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: tends to the right ... tends to the left
tn.text: Here the words "right" and "left" refer to what is right and wrong. AT: "tends to doing what is right ... tends to doing what is wrong" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: his thinking is deficient
tn.text: AT: "he is stupid"

tn.ref: If the emotions of a ruler rise up against you
tn.text: AT: "If a ruler becomes angry with you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Fools are given leadership positions
tn.text: AT: "Rulers give positions of leadership to fools" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: successful men are given low positions
tn.text: AT: "they give low positions to successful men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: General Information:
tn.text: Work is not without risks.

tn.ref: can be hurt by them
tn.text: AT: "those stones can hurt him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: General Information:
tn.text: Some proverbs

tn.ref: wisdom provides an advantage for success
tn.text: A wise person would have sharpened his blade and would not have had to work so hard.

tn.ref: before it is charmed
tn.text: AT: "before the snake charmer charms it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: General Information:
tn.text: Proverbs continued.

tn.ref: The words of a wise man's mouth are gracious
tn.text: AT: "The things that a wise man says are gracious" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: the lips of a fool swallow himself
tn.text: Here the word "swallow" has the sense of destroy. AT: "The things that a foolish man says destroy him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: As words begin to flow from a fool's mouth
tn.text: AT: "As a fool begins to speak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: at the end his mouth flows with wicked madness
tn.text: AT: "as he finishes talking, he speaks wicked madness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: A fool multiplies words
tn.text: AT: "A fool keeps on talking" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: no one knows what is coming
tn.text: See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ecc:08:05|8:7]].

tn.ref: Who knows what is coming after him?
tn.text: The writer asks this question to emphasize that no one know what will happen in the future. AT: "No one knows what is coming after him." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: wearies them
tn.text: "causes them to feel tired"

tn.ref: so that they do not even know the road to town
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) that the foolish person becomes so tired from working too hard that he is unable to find his way anywhere, or 2) that the foolish person becomes tired from working too hard because he does not know enough to go home.

tn.ref: Woe to you, land ... blessed are you, land
tn.text: In these verse, the writer is speaking to the nation as if it were a person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_apostrophe]])

tn.ref: if your king is a young boy
tn.text: This means that the king is inexperienced or immature. Some modern versions, however, interpret the Hebrew word as "a servant."

tn.ref: begin feasting in the morning
tn.text: This implies that the leaders are more concerned with having a good time than with leading the nation.

tn.ref: king is the son of nobles
tn.text: This implies that the son has been trained by his elders in the customs of being a good king.

tn.ref: Because of laziness the roof sinks in
tn.text: A lazy person does not keep up on the regular house maintenance.

tn.ref: because of idle hands
tn.text: AT: "because of an idle person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: People prepare food for laughter
tn.text: AT: "People prepare food in order to laugh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: wine brings enjoyment to life
tn.text: AT: "wine helps people to enjoy life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: money fills the need for everything
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "money provides for every need" or 2) "money provides for both food and wine."

tn.ref: not even in your mind
tn.text: "not even in your thoughts" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: rich people in your bedroom
tn.text: "rich people when you are in your bedroom." This means that you should not curse rich people even when you are in a private place where no one else will hear.

tn.ref: For a bird of the sky ... can spread the matter
tn.text: These two lines mean basically the same thing and are combined for emphasis. The writer uses the metaphor of a bird to say that people will find out what you have said, one way or another. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
